name: Scale Workout
description: Build scale fluency with pentatonic and major scale patterns, starting slow and building speed.

steps.name: Pentatonic Box 1 — Slow
steps.instructions: Play the A minor pentatonic scale in box position 1 (5th fret). Ascend and descend. Use strict alternate picking. One note per beat.
steps.notes: Fingers: index on 5th fret, ring on 7th fret (pinky on 8th where needed).

steps.name: Pentatonic Box 1 — Faster
steps.instructions: Same A minor pentatonic, box 1. Increase to eighth notes — two notes per beat. Keep alternate picking strict. If you stumble, slow down and clean it up.

steps.name: G Major Scale — Full Pattern
steps.instructions: Play the G major scale across all 6 strings in open position. Ascend from low G (3rd fret, 6th string) to high G (3rd fret, 1st string) and back down. One note per beat.
steps.notes: Know your sharps: F# is the only sharp in G major.

steps.name: Scale Sequences — Groups of 3
steps.instructions: Using the G major scale, play in groups of three ascending: 1-2-3, 2-3-4, 3-4-5, etc. Then reverse: 8-7-6, 7-6-5, etc. This builds melodic fluency beyond running scales up and down.
steps.notes: The 3/4 time signature here matches the groups of three nicely.

steps.name: Improvise Over the Scale
steps.instructions: Using the pentatonic or major scale shapes you just practiced, improvise freely. Make up melodies, try bends, slides, and hammer-ons. Have fun with it.
steps.notes: This is where scales become music. Don't just run patterns — try to express something.
